document.title: Abstract Fourier series and Parseval’s identity

para.p:
Let
H
be a separable complex Hilbert space. 1 1 footnote 1 One talk do everything we are doing and obtain the same results for nonseparable Hilbert spaces, but one has to define what uncountable sums mean. This is done in John B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, second ed., chapter I. If
∈
e i
H
,
≥ i 1
, and
=
⟨
e i
,
e j
⟩
δ
i , j
, we say that the set
{
e i
}
is orthonormal. If
⁢ span
{
e i
:
≥ i 1
}
is a dense subspace of
H
, we say that
{
e i
:
≥ i 1
}
is an orthonormal basis for
H
. We can write this in another way. If
∈
S α
, α
I
are subsets of
H
, let
⋁

S α
be the closure of the span of
⋃

S α
. To say that
{
e i
}
is an orthonormal basis for
H
is to say that
{
e i
}
is orthonormal and that
= H
⋁
≥ i 1
{
e i
}
.

If
∈
a k
C
and the sequence
∑

n

a k
e k
converges in
H
, we denote its limit by

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ k * e _ k)

para.p:
This is a definition of an infinite sum in
H
. Since
H
is complete, one usually shows that a sequence converges by showing that the sequence is Cauchy, and hence to show that
∑
= k 1
n
⁢
a k
e k
converges it is equivalent to show that

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = m + 1)) ^ n)@(a _ k * e _ k) to 0

para.p:
as
→
m , n
∞
. And showing this is equivalent to showing that

Math.text: list@(((sum _ (k = m + 1)) ^ n)@(a _ k * e _ k), ((sum _ (k = m + 1)) ^ n)@(a _ k * e _ k)) to 0

para.p:
as
→
m , n
∞
. This is equivalent to

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = m + 1)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(a _ k)) ^ 2) to 0

para.p:
as
→
m , n
∞
, and this is equivalent to the series

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(a _ k)) ^ 2)

para.p:
converging. Thus, the series
∑
= k 1
∞
⁢
a k
e k
converges if and only if the series
∑
= k 1
∞
|
a k
|
2
converges. 2 2 footnote 2 Furthermore, using the triangle inequality rather than the orthonormality of the
e k
, one can check that if the series
∑
= k 1
∞
|
a k
|
converges then the series
∑
= k 1
∞
⁢
a k
e k
converges.

Let
{
e i
:
≥ i 1
}
be an orthonormal basis for
H
; it is a fact that one exists. Let
∈ v H
and define

Math.text: s _ n = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(list@(v, e _ k) * e _ k)

para.p:
If
1 ≤ i ≤ n
then

Math.tex: \left\langle v-s_{n},e_{i}\right\rangle=\left\langle v,e_{i}\right\rangle-\sum% _{k=1}^{n}\left\langle v,e_{k}\right\rangle\left\langle e_{k},e_{i}\right% \rangle=\left\langle v,e_{i}\right\rangle-\left\langle v,e_{i}\right\rangle=0,
Math.text: list@(v - s _ n, e _ i) = list@(v, e _ i) - ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(list@(v, e _ k) * list@(e _ k, e _ i)) = list@(v, e _ i) - list@(v, e _ i) = 0

para.p: hence

Math.text: list@(v - s _ n, s _ n) = 0

para.p: It follows that

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(list@(v, e _ k))) ^ 2) = list@(s _ n, s _ n) less= list@(s _ n, s _ n) + list@(v - s _ n, v - s _ n) = list@(v, v)
((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(list@(v, e _ k))) ^ 2)
list@(s _ n, s _ n)
list@(s _ n, s _ n) + list@(v - s _ n, v - s _ n)
list@(v, v)

para.p:
where we used
=
⟨
- v
s n
,
s n
⟩
0
in the third line. Therefore the series
∑
= k 1

s n
converges to some
v ′

e k
∈ H
. Since
s n
converges to
v ′
, in particular it converges weakly to
v ′
, i.e., for any
∈ w H
,

Math.text: (limit _ (n to infinity))@(list@(s _ n, w)) = list@(v ^ prime, w)

para.p:
Therefore for any
j
,

Math.text: list@(v - v ^ prime, e _ j) = list@(v, e _ j) - list@(v ^ prime, e _ j) = list@(v, v _ j) - (limit _ (n to infinity))@(list@(s _ n, e _ j)) = list@(v, v _ j) - list@(v, v _ j) = 0

para.p:
this is because for
≥ n j
we have
=
⟨
- v
s n
,
e j
⟩
0
and hence
=
⟨ v ,
e j
⟩
⟨
s n
,
e j
⟩
. As
=
⟨
- v
v ′
,
e j
⟩
0
for all
j
, it follows that
=
- v
v ′
0
, i.e.
= v
v ′
. Hence,

Math.text: v = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(list@(v, e _ k) * e _ k)

para.p:
We call this an abstract Fourier series for
v
. 3 3 footnote 3 If
= H

It can be written as

Math.text: v = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((e _ k tensor-product e _ k) * v)

para.p:
and thus can be written without
v
as

Math.text: [id] _ H = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(e _ k tensor-product e _ k)

para.p:
∈
⊗
e k
e k
⁢ B
( H )
is a projection with rank 1, and the above series conveges in the strong operator topology on
⁢ B
( H )
. Writing the identity map in this way is called a resolution of the identity.
On the one hand

Math.text: (limit _ (n to infinity))@((norm@(s _ n)) ^ 2) = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(list@(v, e _ k))) ^ 2)

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: (limit _ (n to infinity))@((norm@(s _ n)) ^ 2) = (norm@(v)) ^ 2

para.p: Hence

Math.text: (norm@(v)) ^ 2 = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(list@(v, e _ k))) ^ 2)

para.p: which is Parseval’s identity.
